Key Arguments: The authors support the direction of the legislation but suggest further refinement is needed.
They emphasize the importance of freedom of expression and recommend a statement of high-level principles to reinforce this.
They highlight the need for clearer definitions of misinformation and disinformation, focusing on harm rather than intent.
Concerns are raised about content exemptions, particularly regarding professional news and electoral content.
They suggest clarifying the scope of private message exemptions to avoid potential privacy issues.
They recommend harmonizing terms and definitions with similar legislation for consistency.
Notable Quotes: We commend the Department... on its work to combat misinformation and disinformation by considering new ACMA powers to tackle this global problem.

To avoid unnecessary censorship concerns... we recommend a statement of high-level principles at the outset of the bill to reinforce Australia’s commitments to the value of open, pluralistic communication in a liberal democracy.

We recommend better harmonisation with the existing DIGI definition and the one applied by ACMA that will take into account the difficulty of ‘intention’ by focusing instead on decisive actions that spread information that can mislead, deceive or otherwise cause harm.
